S0926-860X(16)30385-4 10.1016/j.apcata.2016.07.016 Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of the experimental apparatus for natural gas steam reforming (NGSR) reaction system (MFC: Mass Flow controller). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Photos of top and lateral view of monolith catalysts coated by (a) conventional washcoating and (b) proprietary KIER coating. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 SEM images of monolith catalysts coated by (a) conventional washcoating and (b) KIER coating. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and BJH pore size distribution (inset) of the monolith catalysts obtained under different coating methods. (a) washcoating and (b) KIER coating method. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Comparison of (a) CH4 conversion and (b) outer wall temperature of tubular reactor with different GHSV over Ni/MgAl2O4 pellet catalyst and monolith catalysts prepared by conventional washcoating and KIER coating in natural gas steam reforming (reaction condition: Tcat =700°C, S/C=3). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 CH4 conversion with the time on stream (TOS) of monolith catalysts prepared by conventional washcoating and KIER coating in natural gas steam reforming (reaction condition: Tcat =700°C, S/C=3, GHSV=15,000h−1). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Photos and SEM images of used monolith catalysts after natural gas steam reforming (reaction condition: Tcat =700°C, S/C=3, GHSV=15,000h−1, TOS=70h). Fig. 7 Table 1 Ni loading amount and textural characteristics of monolith catalysts prepared by KIER coating and washcoating method. Table 1 Monolith Catalyst Ni loading (mg/cm2) BET surface area (m2/g) a Pore volume (cm3/g) a Average pore diameter (nm) a Ni dispersion (%) b Ni surface area (m2/g) b KIER coating 0.52 99 0.26 9.2 3.0 20 Washcoating 0.63 35 0.16 17 1.7 12 a Estimated from N2 adsorption at −196°C. b Estimated form H2-chemisorption at 50°C. Table 2 Gas product composition in NGSR on stream (reaction condition: Tcat =700°C, S/C=3, GHSV=15,000h−1). Table 2 Gas product composition (mol%) CH4 CO CO2 H2 Initial 70h Initial 70h Initial 70h Initial 70h KIER coating 1.25 1.32 9.42 9.34 14.53 14.79 74.80 74.55 Washcoating 1.18 1.79 10.65 9.96 13.31 13.48 74.86 74.77 Table 3 EDS data of used monolith catalysts after NGSR (reaction condition: Tcat =700°C, S/C=3, GHSV=15,000h−1, TOS=70h). Table 3 Monolith Catalyst Ni Al O Fe Cr Mg KIER coating 28.4 12.8 56.2 1.8 0.8 – Washcoating 3.9 22.6 62.9 0.3 0 10.3 Ni nanosheet-coated monolith catalyst with high performance for hydrogen production via natural gas steam reforming Kee Young Koo Hyun Ji Eom Un Ho Jung Wang Lai Yoon ⁎ Hydrogen Laboratory, Korea Institute of Energy Research (KIER), 152 Gajeong-ro, Yuseong-gu, Daejeon 34129, Republic of Korea Hydrogen Laboratory Korea Institute of Energy Research (KIER) 152 Gajeong-ro Yuseong-gu Daejeon 34129 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A Ni nanosheet-coated FeCrAlloy monolith catalyst was successfully prepared using a deposition-precipitation-based “Korea Institute of Energy Research” (KIER) coating method, which provides a uniform coating of highly dispersive Ni catalyst on the metal substrate. The newly developed monolith catalyst showed a higher Ni dispersion and surface area on the substrate as compared to a washcoated monolith catalyst. The Ni nanosheet-coated monolith catalyst exhibited high activity and long-lasting stability at a high space velocity of GHSV=15,000h−1 during a natural gas steam reforming reaction for H2 production. This is mainly attributed to the fact that the uniform and highly dispersed Ni nanosheet catalyst improves the availability of surface active metal sites on the metal substrate. Keywords Ni nanosheet Catalyst coating Monolith Steam reforming Hydrogen production 1 Introduction Most chemical processes are accompanied by the evolution or absorption of reaction heat. Natural gas steam reforming (NGSR) for hydrogen production in a fuel reformer is strongly endothermic and, hence, requires a large amount of reaction heat [1]. A conventional packed bed reactor that uses a ceramic pellet catalyst is inefficient owing to the low thermal conductivity and mass transfer limitations, resulting in the disadvantage of unnecessarily large reactor volume [2]. According to a study by Xu and Froment [3], the effectiveness factor of the steam reforming catalyst is around 0.03; thus, only active sites on the outer surface of the pellet catalyst participate in the reaction. From the perspective of reaction kinetics, the diffusion of a gaseous reactant to the surface of the catalyst becomes the rate-limiting step owing to a rapid surface reaction at temperatures above 700°C. Therefore, it is imperative to develop a new reactor technology to address various drawbacks such as channeling, pressure drop, low thermal conductivity, and slow systemic response in existing fixed bed reactors that are packed with ceramic pellet catalysts [4–6]. A structured catalyst is a very useful core technology in reactions that exhibit a rate-limiting diffusion of gaseous reactants toward the catalyst surface [2,7]. The main advantage of a metallic structured catalytic reactor is that it can increase the heat transfer rate per unit volume (US/V, intensification factor), while providing a large geometrical reaction surface to reaction volume ratio (S/V, compacity factor) [8]. In addition, highly regular reactor channels can provide a uniform fluid flow to minimize systemic pressure drop, as well as concentration and temperature radial gradients [9,10]. In particular, metal monolith catalysts have attracted a great deal of attention as alternatives to conventional pellet catalysts. According to a previous study by Roh et al. [11], a stainless steel-supported (SUS) Ni catalyst monolith showed higher activity compared to a pellet catalyst during an NGSR reaction owing to its higher heat transfer efficiency. Moreover, Bobadilla et al. [12] showed that a Ni-Sn/MgO-CeO2/Al2O3-coated metal monolith used in glycerol steam reforming had superior activity and stability compared to conventional powder and spherical pellet catalysts. Unlike the case of a packed bed reactor, reactants easily flow through the channels of a monolith catalyst, thereby mitigating pressure drop and channeling problems [13,14]. In addition, a metal monolith reactor provides a more compact and lighter reaction system owing to its improved heat and mass transfer capabilities, which in turn increases the reactor throughput as a result of the higher capacity per unit reactor volume and hour [15–17]. However, in order to commercialize this technology, the catalyst of choice has to be deposited stably, and should be highly dispersed on the surface of a metallic substrate to afford high activity and long-term stability. Therefore, it is necessary to devise a proper coating method using a highly dispersed catalyst to maximize the number of exposed active sites, which are responsible for the fast surface reaction at high space velocity, and to prevent the sintering of the catalyst particles at high temperatures [18,19]. In particular, a monolith in the shape of a long-channel honeycomb makes it difficult to achieve an even catalyst coating within the channel owing to capillary forces. As such, it is essential to develop an efficient coating strategy to afford a highly dispersed deposition of the catalyst in order to improve the activity and stability of the metal monolith catalyst [20]. Some previous studies have reviewed the different coating methods used in depositing the catalyst of interest on metallic structured substrates, and conventional coating methods such as impregnation and washcoating (slurry coating) are typically the main choices [5,21,22]. As reported in previous works, the impregnation method results in minimal catalyst deposition and has difficulties in controlling the catalyst dispersion, while it is challenging to control the thickness of the coating layer using the washcoating method, especially when it comes to achieving an even layer of catalyst coating [23]. Benito et al. [24] have highlighted the problem of non-uniformity in metal dispersion on a structured catalyst when the impregnation method is used and emphasized the necessity to achieve a highly dispersed active metal deposition on the surface of the structured support. An electrosynthesis procedure was used to coat Rh/Mg/Al hydrotalcite-type compounds on FeCrAlloy foams for the catalytic partial oxidation of CH4. However, the ability to control the composition of the deposited catalyst, which affects the metallic particle size and adhesion of the film, remains an unresolved issue. According to Fukuhara et al. [25], a honeycomb-type Ni-based catalyst was prepared by using a combination of the sol-gel and electroless plating methods on a stainless steel substrate. In other words, the structured catalyst consisted of a porous alumina layer formed by the sol-gel method, whereas the nickel component was deposited via electroless plating. They reported that the monolith structure that was washcoated with a commercial catalyst showed lower activity compared to the prepared honeycomb catalyst in a methane dry reforming reaction. Therefore, the present study focuses on developing a new coating technique (named the Korea Institute of Energy Research (KIER) technique), based on a general deposition-precipitation method, to provide an effective control of catalyst deposition and to achieve a high dispersion of the Ni catalyst particles. The results obtained using the newly developed catalyst system were compared to the activity of a metal monolith catalyst, which was prepared using a conventional washcoating method, via an NGSR reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation A FeCrAlloy (Goodfellow, Fe: 72.8, Cr: 22, Al: 5, Y: 0.1, Zr: 0.1wt%) monolith (used as a metal structured carrier) was manufactured by rolling flat and corrugated metal strips into the shape of a cylinder. The diameter of the cylinder was 22mm, the height was 20mm, and the cell density was 690 cpi (cells/in2). The metal monolith catalyst was prepared by the following process. Firstly, the metal surface was rinsed with acetone in an ultrasonic bath for 0.5h and subsequently, electrochemically treated with aqueous HF solution at an electrical voltage of 5eV. After the preliminary treatment of the metal surface, it was calcined at 900°C for 6h. We previously showed that the Al2O3 layer formed on the pre-treated surface of a FeCrAlloy substrate enhanced the adherence between the metal substrate and the coated catalyst layer, thus resulting in a more stable catalytic performance compared to a system that had only undergone a conventional thermal oxidation treatment (900°C, 6h) [19]. The pre-calcined monolith was repeatedly washcoated with a 10wt% Al2O3 sol solution until a sufficient Al2O3 amount was loaded onto the metal monolith, after which the Al2O3-coated monolith was re-calcined at 900°C for 6h. A 10wt% Al2O3 sol solution was prepared by dissolving boehmite (Disperal P2, Sasol) in distilled water. The viscosity of the Al2O3 sol solution was kept constant by maintaining the solution’s pH at 4.5. In order to use Ni as the main active metal of the catalytic system, nickel nitrate (97%, Junsei) was used as the catalyst precursor in a proprietary KIER coating technique based on a general deposition-precipitation method, along with the addition of an ammonia solution (28%, Junsei) as a precipitating agent to control the pH of the coating solution at 13.0 [26]. After the loading of Ni, the monolith was calcined at 700°C for 2h. To compare different coating methods, the monolith catalyst was also prepared via washcoating using a 15wt% Ni/MgAl2O4 catalyst slurry, which is a mixture of 15wt% Ni/MgAl2O4 catalyst powder, Al2O3 sol, and distilled water in the ratio of 1:1:4. We prepared the powder catalyst by grinding the 15wt% Ni/MgAl2O4 pellet catalyst finely. The washcoated monolith was calcined at 600°C for 3h. Meanwhile, a 15wt% Ni/MgAl2O4 pellet catalyst (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area=22m2/g, Ni dispersion=1.9% and Ni surface area=13m2/g) was prepared via an impregnation method using a nickel nitrate solution on a MgAl2O4 spinel (1-hole, Sasol) pellet. The pellet catalyst was calcined at 700°C for 2h. The Ni coating amount per unit area of monolith catalyst was calculated according to Eq. (1). (1) Ni coating amount (g/cm2)=(W1-W)/A Where W is the metal monolith’s weight (g), W1 is the coated metal monolith’s weight (g), and A is the surface area of the metal monolith (cm2). 2.2 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and BET surface area of the monolith catalyst were measured using a BELSORP-Max instrument (BEL Japan, Inc.). To measure a whole monolith sample, a homemade cell was used. Before the analysis, the sample was treated at 200°C for 3h in vacuum, followed by a N2 adsorption at −196°C. The pore size distribution was calculated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. H2-chemisorption was performed to identify the metal surface area and metallic dispersion using the BEL-METAL-3 instrument (BEL Japan, Inc.). A 0.3g sample which was prepared by cutting the coated monolith in a proper size was reduced under a H2 gas flow at 700°C for 3h. The sample was then purged at 700°C for 1h under a He gas flow and subsequently cooled to 50°C. A H2 pulse (20 vol.% H2/Ar) was then injected into the catalyst. The adsorbed H2 amount, obtained by assuming the adsorption stoichiometry of one hydrogen atom per nickel atom on the surface (H/Nisurface =1), was used to estimate the Ni dispersion and surface area. The surface morphology of the monolith catalyst, the shape of the coated catalyst particle, and the composition of the metal substrate were observed using scanning electron microscopy (SEM; S-4700, Hitachi, Japan) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS; EMAX 7200-H, Horiba, Japan). 2.3 Catalyst reaction Fig. 1 shows the schematic diagram of the experimental apparatus used for the NGSR reaction system. The test reaction was performed at 700°C under atmospheric pressure in a one-inch diameter Inconel tubular reactor (O.D.=25.4mm, I.D.=22.1mm), and the thermocouple was located at the bottom center of the monolith. Prior to the reaction, the catalyst was reduced at 700°C for 3h in 20 vol.% H2/N2 balance. Reactants were fed with a steam-to-carbon (S/C) ratio of 3 (mol/mol), and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 6000–15,000h−1. The effluent was passed through a trap to condense residual water and analyzed with an on-line micro-gas chromatograph (Agilent 3000), equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The compositions of H2, N2, CH4, and CO were detected with a Molsieve column, as well as the CO2 composition was determined in a PLOT U column. The CH4 conversion was calculated as follows: C H 4 conversion ( % ) F C H 4 i n − F C H 4 o u t F C H 4 i n × 100 where F C H 4 i n and F C H 4 o u t are the molar flow rates of the inlet and outlet CH4 gas, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of Ni catalyst coating method Catalyst deactivation caused by particle sintering is a major obstacle in developing metal structured catalyst with high activity and good stability. The sintering of Ni catalyst particles which results from high temperature steam oxidation and thermal shock incurred during the startup and shutdown of repetitive steam reforming reaction tests, decreases the surface area of the active sites and thus, deactivates the metal structured catalyst [27]. In addition, for a steam reforming reaction that occurs at high temperature, only the active sites on the surface participate in the reaction as the surface reaction is faster than the mass transfer [18]. Hence, it is essential to ensure that the catalyst particles are highly dispersed on the surface of the metal structured carrier. Fig. 2 (a) and (b) shows images of the monolith catalysts prepared by the washcoating and KIER coating methods, respectively. For the monolith catalyst prepared via washcoating (using a 15wt% Ni/MgAl2O4 catalyst slurry), the thick coating layer caused channel blockage as well as cracked monolith surface. On the contrary, the monolith catalyst prepared by the new coating technique was coated with a layer of Ni with constant thickness, without any channel blockage. In particular, the thickness of coated catalyst layer was confirmed from the cross-sectional images via the SEM analysis in Fig. 3 . The washcoated monolith catalyst showed much thicker coating layer (21μm) than the KIER-coated monolith catalyst (1.1μm). It is evident that the thin coating layer of Ni catalyst was formed on the monolith surface using the KIER coating method. SEM analysis of the coated catalyst surface layer revealed that the catalyst particles aggregated on the surface of the washcoated monolith. Moreover, the catalyst surface was rough and uneven (Fig. 3). Akhlaghian et al. [28] have demonstrated that the cracked surface of the washcoated layer is attributed to the different thermal expansion coefficients between the FeCrAlloy and the coated layer, as well as the shrinkage of the washcoated layer during drying and calcination. From this result, it was evident that the thickness and evenness of the coated layer could not be effectively controlled by the washcoating method. Additionally, it was possible to predict that a weak adherence between the thick coated layer and the metal structured carrier caused a detachment of the catalyst layer from the metal substrate’s surface. Interestingly, in the case of the monolith that was prepared by the KIER coating method, thin plate-like shaped NiO nanosheet particles were observed. They were formed as uniformly arranged petals on the surface of the metal substrate. The Ni loading amount per unit area of the prepared metal monolith catalyst and its textural characteristics are summarized in Table 1 . The amounts of Ni loaded per unit area of each metal monolith catalyst prepared using the KIER coating and washcoating methods were 0.52mg/cm2 and 0.63mg/cm2, respectively. We recalculated the BET surface area based solely on the weight of the coating (i.e., disregarding the total weight of the monolith) because the BET surface area of the monolith without any coating was very low [12]. Fig. 4 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and BJH pore size distributions of the prepared monolith catalysts. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of the monolith catalyst prepared via the washcoating method was a type IV isotherm with a typical H3 hysteresis loop, as shown in Fig. 4(a). The monolith catalyst showed a wide range of pore size distribution, from 10 to 90nm, and the pore volume was 0.16cm3/g. This H3 hysteresis loop isotherm corresponded to agglomerated particles with a broad pore size distribution and is similar to the result reported by Bodabilla et al. [12]. Meanwhile, the monolith catalyst prepared via the KIER coating method showed a type H1 hysteresis loop and a relatively uniform pore size distribution. The primary and secondary pore size distributions were measured at 4 and 11nm, respectively. In addition, the BET surface area and pore volume were 99m2/g and 0.26cm3/g, respectively. Moreover, it was confirmed that the KIER-coated monolith catalyst had higher Ni dispersion and metallic surface area than the washcoated monolith catalyst from the H2-chemisorption result. It should be noteworthy that Ni nanosheet catalysts with large surface area and pore volume can be coated on the meatal substrate by the ingenious KIER coating method. The textural properties of the catalyst play an important role in determining its activity and stability. In a previous work, a Ni/Al2O3 catalyst with a leaf-like nanostructure and large pore volume demonstrated improved activity during a methane dry reforming reaction as these distinct physical properties provided large structural channels to improve the diffusion of reactants and products [29]. In addition, Dong et al. [30] described the effects of the specific catalyst surface area and pore size distribution, and reported that the use of porous NiO nanosheets enhanced the photocatalytic activity for NO degradation. The KIER coating method enables the surface area and pore system of an active metal that is coated on a metal substrate to be controlled effectively. It can also optimize the surface of the metal monolith so that more active sites of the Ni catalyst can actually participate in the reaction. 3.2 Catalytic test in natural gas steam reforming reaction In order to examine the activity of the different monolith catalysts, an NGSR reaction was performed. Fig. 5 (a) shows the varying CH4 conversion corresponding to a change in the reaction gas flow rate. As the reaction gas flow rate increases, the increase in GHSV causes a mass transfer limitation owing to an increased diffusion resistance; thus, the reaction will mainly take place on the catalyst surface. This means that the activity of the catalyst is positively correlated to the amount of active metal sites on the catalyst surface. According to Heck et al. [7], a reaction is limited by the mass transfer from the reacting species to the catalyst surface when the reaction rate is very fast. They have also stressed that it is necessary to use more active catalysts, higher catalyst loading, or higher operating temperatures to obtain mass transfer-controlled reactions in monolith reactors. The effect of catalyst loading method on the catalytic activity was examined, and it was revealed that the monolith catalyst prepared by the KIER coating method resulted in a higher CH4 conversion compared to the conventional washcoating method. When GHSV=10,000h−1, the CH4 conversion was 94% using the washcoating method but the KIER coating method afforded an impressive 97.4% conversion. This shows the importance of obtaining evenly dispersed Ni particles on the metal substrate, which markedly improved the activity of the Ni-coated monolith catalyst. This observation is consistent with the structural characterization result obtained from the SEM analysis. In addition, a comparative performance test of the metal monolith and pellet catalysts was also performed. When GHSV=6000h−1, both the pellet and monolith catalysts had a similar CH4 conversion in the vicinity of thermodynamic equilibrium value. Nonetheless, when the flow rate was increased by 2.5 times, the monolith catalyst showed a higher CH4 conversion compared to the pellet catalyst. Assuming that the reaction occurs primarily on the catalyst surface owing to an increase in the reactant gas flow rate, the resulting diffusion resistance would render the active metal within the pellet catalyst ineffective, thus lowering the conversion. In contrast, the monolith catalyst showed a much better catalytic performance as a result of an increased availability of surface Ni particles on the metal substrate in spite of the lower amount of coated Ni, as well as improved heat transfer during the reaction. To compare the heat transfer capability of the pellet catalyst and monolith catalysts, we monitored the outer wall temperature of tubular reactor at Tcat =700°C. In Fig. 5(b), as the GHSV is increased, the temperature difference between the catalyst bed and the outer wall temperature of reactor is large. It is due to the fact that a large amount of reaction heat is required as the reactant gas flow rate increases in a strong endothermic reaction like NGSR reaction. In general, the temperature difference between the catalyst bed and the outer wall temperature of reactor becomes smaller as the heat transfer from the furnace to the catalyst bed is more efficient. It is evident that the metal monolith catalysts showed smaller temperature difference than the pellet catalyst due to the good heat transfer capability. This result is in agreement with our previous reports [11,15]. If the packed bed reactor were to process a sizeable amount of reactant gas per unit time, a huge amount of pellet catalyst would be required to obtain the desired level of conversion, and this would lead to an inevitable enlargement of the reactor [31]. However, when an improved metal structured catalyst (i.e., synthesized by evenly coating a small amount of catalyst on the metal substrate’s surface) was applied to the reformer, the reactor size could be optimized to reduce its footprint. In other words, by using a performance-enhanced reactor, which needs only a minimal amount of the active catalyst, the size of the reactor could be reduced to process more reactant gas flow per unit volume of the catalyst [5,6,32]. The metal structured catalyst has higher activity owing to the highly dispersed catalyst on the metal substrate, as well as good heat transfer; hence, it is evidently better suited for producing hydrogen via NGSR compared to the conventional pellet catalyst. This demonstrates the importance of using the right active metal coating method to maximize the availability of surface catalyst on the metal substrate of choice. Fig. 6 shows the percentage of CH4 conversion plotted against the time on stream (TOS) using monolith catalysts that were prepared via the washcoating and KIER coating methods in an NGSR reaction. The reaction was carried out at 700°C, with S/C=3, and GHSV=15,000h−1. Table 2 summarizes the gas product composition in an NGSR reaction. The monolith catalyst that was prepared by the KIER coating method showed 95% CH4 conversion and stable activity up to the maximum tested duration of 70h. While the washcoated monolith catalyst first showed a similar level of activity, the activity gradually decreased after 40h from the point of initiation. Fig. 7 shows the photos and SEM images of the used monolith catalysts after undergoing an NGSR test for 70h. It was clear that the washcoated monolith catalyst showed irregularly agglomerated catalyst particles, with cracks on the catalyst surface. On the other hand, the KIER-coated monolith catalyst had an extremely uniform coating layer on the metal substrate, even after undergoing the NGSR test at 700°C. The cross-sectional SEM images showed that the washcoated catalyst layer was detached from the surface of the used monolith. On the other hand, the KIER-coated catalyst layer adhered uniformly and stably to the surface of the metal substrate. Table 3 summarizes the elemental atomic ratio that was detected on the surface of the used monolith catalysts obtained via an EDS analysis. The Ni amount on the surface of the monolith catalyst that was prepared via the KIER coating method was higher than that of the washcoated monolith catalyst, suggesting that more Ni metal was exposed on the surface of the KIER-coated monolith catalyst. Moving forward, we aim to investigate the changes in textural properties, particle shape, and activity of the KIER-coated monolith catalyst by varying the amount of Ni used in an NGSR reaction. 4 Conclusions The KIER coating technique (based on a general deposition-precipitation method) was developed to efficiently coat a uniform layer of Ni nanosheet catalyst on the surface of the FeCrAlloy monolith. This method enabled the Ni catalyst layer to be coated on the entire surface of the metal substrate without any monolith channel blockage, thus addressing a serious problem faced by the conventional washcoating method. The KIER-coated monolith showed higher activity and long-lasting stability in a test NGSR reaction compared to the washcoated monolith catalyst. This was attributed to the fact that the activity of the FeCrAlloy monolith catalyst was improved by the highly dispersed Ni nanosheet catalyst deposited on the surface of the metal substrate. More specifically, the Ni nanosheet catalyst, which has a large surface area and high metal dispersion, improved in the availability of surface active metal sites on the metal substrate. The metal monolith catalyst showed much better activity than a pellet catalyst at higher space velocity because of the improved heat transfer capability. Therefore, the KIER coating method, which produces an enhanced metal structured catalyst, could lead to a considerable reduction in the size of the reactor used for hydrogen production via an NGSR reaction. Acknowledgements This work was supported by the New & Renewable Energy of the Korea Institute of Energy Technology Evaluation and Planning (KETEP), granted financial resource from the Ministry of Trade, Industry & Energy, Republic of Korea. (20123010040010). coredata.dc:description: A Ni nanosheet-coated FeCrAlloy monolith catalyst was successfully prepared using a deposition-precipitation-based “Korea Institute of Energy Research” (KIER) coating method, which provides a uniform coating of highly dispersive Ni catalyst on the metal substrate. The newly developed monolith catalyst showed a higher Ni dispersion and surface area on the substrate as compared to a washcoated monolith catalyst. The Ni nanosheet-coated monolith catalyst exhibited high activity and long-lasting stability at a high space velocity of GHSV=15,000h−1 during a natural gas steam reforming reaction for H2 production. This is mainly attributed to the fact that the uniform and highly dispersed Ni nanosheet catalyst improves the availability of surface active metal sites on the metal substrate.
coredata.dc:title: Ni nanosheet-coated monolith catalyst with high performance for hydrogen production via natural gas steam reforming
